Find the positive integer $n$ such that
\[\sin \left( \frac{\pi}{2n} \right) + \cos \left (\frac{\pi}{2n} \right) = \frac{\sqrt{n}}{2}.\]
inference:
Squaring both sides, we get
\[\sin^2 \left( \frac{\pi}{2n} \right) + 2 \sin \left( \frac{\pi}{2n} \right) \cos \left( \frac{\pi}{2n} \right) + \cos^2 \left( \frac{\pi}{2n} \right) = \frac{n}{4}.\]Then $1 + \sin \left( \frac{\pi}{n} \right) = \frac{n}{4},$ so
\[\sin \left( \frac{\pi}{n} \right) = \frac{n}{4} - 1.\]Since $-1 \le \sin \left( \frac{\pi}{n} \right) \le 1,$ $-1 \le \frac{n}{4} - 1 \le 1,$ so $0 \le \frac{n}{4} \le 2.$  This means $0 \le n \le 8.$

We can check the integers $n$ from 1 to 8.  We find that $n = \boxed{4}$ works.  Note that $n = 8$ also works, but we want the smallest such $n.$
